Headline: History of Egan Warming Centers
Text:
After Thomas Egan died in 2008, the cold-weather shelters that bear his name have gone through different incarnations.

Swipe or click on the arrow to the right to step through their history, the story continues below.

Headline: Thomas Egan passes away
Text:
Passerby finds Thomas Egan's body near West First Avenue and Blair Boulevard, a bottle of liquor by his side.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Major Thomas Egan, who froze to death on the streets of Eugene during a snowstorm, during his deployment in Korea.

Headline: Memorial
Text:
Memorial service for Egan held at National Guard armory in Eugene.

Read more here.
Media Caption: A flag is spread in honor of former National Guard member Thomas Egan during a memorial service at the National Guard auditorium in January 2009. (Kevin Clark/The Register-Guard)

Headline: EGAN Shelter Coalition
Text:
The Lane County Board of Commissioners voted unanimously to designate the county-owned National Guard armory as an emergency cold weather shelter, and organizers create "EGAN Shelter Coalition."

Read more here.

Headline: First Egan Memorial Warming Center
Text:
Egan Memorial Warming Center staff and volunteers gear up to provide winter-long emergency shelter when temperatures drop below 28 degrees.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Michael Hodgin, who calls himself "Hobo," sits on a cot in the warming center at First Christian Church. He was one of several homeless men who volunteered Thursday night to help set up the temporary dormitory. A room with 50 cots and blankets at the downtown church was one of two warming centers set up in Eugene. (Paul Carter/The Register-Guard)

Headline: Second anniversary
Text:
Memorial held near where Egan's body was found in the Whiteaker neighborhood, to commemorate the second anniversary of his death.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Kate Saunders, a friend of Thomas Egan, points to the spot where he died at a memorial event on December 17, 2010. (Paul Carter/The Register-Guard)

Headline: Occupy Eugene
Text:
Homeless encampment takes shape in Washington-Jefferson Park during Occupy Eugene protest, but several homeless people say they feel much safer staying at one of the Egan Warming Center sites.

Read more here.

Headline: Growing pains
Text:
As program continues to grow, warming center officials put out call for more volunteers.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Volunteers set up cots and mats at the Ebbert Methodist Memorial Church in December 2015, one of the host sites for the Egan Warming Centers. (Kelly Lyon/The Register-Guard)

Headline: Lending a helping hand
Text:
Program officials say more than 1,100 guests served during winter of 2013-14.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Troy Nipper settles in for the night at one of the Egan Warming Centers set up in the fellowship hall of Dayspring Ministries in Eugene in January 2011. (Chris Pietsch/The Register-Guard)

Headline: More volunteers needed
Text:
Lack of volunteers forces warming center sites to stay closed on cold nights.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Rob Tobias, a volunteer musician for the Egan Warming Center at Ebbert Methodist Memorial Church in Springfield gets ready to play for about 60 guests on a Wednesday night in December 2015. (Kelly Lyon/The Register-Guard)

Headline: Giving and receiving
Text:
Warming center volunteers talk about the experience.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Volunteers Rose Nelson, left, Lori Greig Lawson and Elizabeth Lane, right, make sandwiches for guests at the Egan Warming Centers set up in the fellowship hall of Dayspring Ministries at 1580 River Road in January 2011. (Chris Pietsch/The Register-Guard)

Headline: Recent changes
Text:
After local fire officials say two warming center sites could no longer be used, organizers secure new location, inside former school district administration building in Springfield.

Read more here.

Headline: 10 years later
Text:
Candlelight vigil marks 10 years since Egan's death.

Read more here.
Media Caption: Executive Director of the Eugene Mission Sheryl Balthrop, right, and her husband David Balthrop joins Egan Warming Center Director Shelley Courteville, right, at a candle light vigil in memory of Tom Eagan on the 10th anniversary of his death. (Chris Pietsch/The Register-Guard)
